oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Photograph of Freshman Class of LeMoyne College, 1941-42
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Black and white photograph of 1941 freshman class of LeMoyne College, taken in front of Brown Lee Hall on the campus of LeMoyne College in Memphis, Tennessee. The class is arranged in four rows. Many of the people in the photograph are identified by Lovelle Fouse Jenkins. Future civil rights leader Reverend Benjamin L. Hooks is in the far right on the back row of the photograph. LeMoyne-Owen College is a private HBCU that opened during the Civil War. LeMoyne merged with Owen College in 1968, and is still in operation today.

Education was a key pillar of African American political activity, especially for women. In July 1920, the National Association of Colored Women's Clubs met in Tuskegee Alabama for their annual conference. At the convention a Resolution on Federal Suffrage was passed that established the political agenda for African American women as soon as they obtained suffrage with the 19th Amendment. The political platform included: building libraries, education, healthcare, preserving and documenting black history, temperance, anti-lynching laws, and enforcing the 14th and 15th Amendments.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Hooks, Benjamin L. (Benjamin Lawson), 1925-2010; Jenkins, Lovell Fouse, 1923-2007
LeMoyne College; LeMoyne-Owen College
